ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed knowledge about the politics of the early American period. The course is also a lens into the lives of Jefferson and Hamilton, and a reevaluation of both based on primary evidence. This class has a super interesting focus on primary sources (Jefferson and Hamiltons correspondence) which makes it incredibly interesting, and unique from other courses. Also, I learned how to structure and write a 20+ page pape grounded in primary evidence.
Learned about evaluating primary sources and how to write a real research paper
I learned how to write a long research paper and do research in the archives. I also learned how to read founding letters/diaries and analyze them thoroughly.

I learn how to write a primary source research paper (from idea proposal to prospectus to research to draft to final product). This was super valuable to take before the senior thesis (and made me really excited for that process)!
Deep engagement with Hamiltons and Jeffersons letters and lives

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Prof. Freeman. If you have any interest at all in the period, consider taking a class with her. She line-edits all of the rough drafts (for a 20+ page paper, this is very generous!) and is engaged throughout the course, meeting with you about the prospectus and rough draft. Honestly, if youre on the fence about this course, consider taking it just to learn from her.

Weaknesses: I think it would help to have a mini-lecture in the first or second class, to cement a background of the period. There were lots of historical clarification questions during the semester, so it would help to dispel some of those questions earlier on. We usually did not get through all of the readings, but thats a minor complaint  the letters are all really interesting.
Professor Freeman is so impressive. She LINE EDITS every single sentence of your rough draft for your 20 page papers. This is truly remarkable!

Professor Freeman is the course's strength for sure. I loved all of her stories about the founders that she's picked up from her education, research, and love of the work she does. It was really cool to spend a semester reading primary source documents and to learn for the sake of learning!
everything is rooted in primary sources and prof freeman is so knowledgable

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If interested in American history, absolutely! It has a primary source focus on Jefferson and Hamilton, so it might not be as interesting for non-U.S. history/American Studies majors. Nevertheless, the skills gained appeal to a broad range of majors and interests.

Yes!!! Professor Freeman is a gem. The week-to-week workload for this course is low, but the writing of the paper is a big commitment. Regardless, I really feel like I learned how to write a research paper which is a skill I will take with me forever. Professor Freeman also really teaches you how to write a paper like this, she doesn't expect you to know. Plus, the content is super interesting. Take this class!

Yes, if you are interested in the time period and Professor Freeman is super impressive. That being said, I am not the biggest fan of the homework assignments and didn't feel like I learned a lot from them because I was focused on my final paper.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student! This course will really teach you how to write and will get you in the minds of Hamilton and Jefferson.
Yes! Absolutely take it if you get in!
yeah, it was cool to learn about the personality of the founding fathers, what they were worried about in the formation of the nation, what parallels we can see today even, etc.

extras.title: HIST 135J 01 - Age of Hamilton and Jefferson
